conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to calculate the change in magnetic flux through the coil as it rotates around the z-axis.
The magnetic flux is given by the product of the area of the coil and the magnetic induction intensity.
The coil ABCO is shown in the figure, with the rotation angle of 60° downward around the z-axis.
Area of the coil ABCO = 0.4 m² and magnetic induction intensity B = 0.1 T.
The change in magnetic flux ΔW can be calculated using the formula ΔW = Area of the coil × Change in magnetic induction intensity.
Since the magnetic induction intensity changes due to the rotation of the coil, we need to determine the change in magnetic induction intensity.
The change in magnetic induction intensity ΔB is calculated as ΔB = B × cos(60°).
The change in magnetic flux is calculated as ΔW = 0.4 m² × 0.1 T × 0.5.
Performing the multiplication gives ΔW = 0.4 × 0.1 × 0.5 = 0.02 Weber.
Since the change in magnetic flux is a decrease, the final magnetic flux W is 0.02 Weber.
The change in magnetic flux is 0.02 Webers.
